SECT. XLVII. ].

Notes.

[[283]]

cognition which is conveyed by the ‡§â‡§™‡§®‡§Ø in & ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, and which thereupon produces the aft in the hearer’s mind. If then qraf must be recognized as the r of a ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø, why have separate ‡§ï‡§∞r for the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø, when the same can do for both? This reasoning is faultless, except that according to those who define ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ 28 ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§¶- ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£, ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂ cannot be the ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ as it has no ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞ coming after it. Hence the advocates of this definition of

‡§ï‡§∞‡§£.

Tor, namely, the ancient Naiy√¢yikas, propose amara to be the ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ and ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂ to be its ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞, while the moderns who deny the necessity of ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ and define ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ 25 ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ- ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç regard ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂ itself as the ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£. Annam- bhatta seems really to be vascilating between these two views, although in the text he has made the emphatic decla- ration ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç, and his vascilation is due to his non-preference for either of the two definitions of . At least there is a glaring inconsistency between this pas- sage and the concluding remarks of Sect. 43 where he de- clares ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø to be the ‡§ï‡§∞r of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ * Had it not been for those remarks, it could have been said with much plausibi- lity that, notwithstanding his obvious indecision as to the real definition of a ror, Annambhatta adopted the modern in preference to the ancient view. Probably he did so, and the statement about the of erg was made simply in deference to the popular convention which from time im- memorial has regarded ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø to be the ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ and has thereby made the very word ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ synonymous with ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø- The book being intended for beginners the author appears to have avoided all fruitless controversies as much as possible, and hence sometimes fell into inconsistencies.

  1. The reading arm in the first part of this section is obviously wrong, although it is found in all Mss. except two. It is probably an emendation of some later copyist, who having noticed the inconsistency of this passage with Sect. 41 thought of removing it by improving the text.

*See p. 32; and Note 3 thereon p. 224, Supra,

[[284]]

Tarka-Sangraha.

SECT. XLVIII. fam

[ SHOT. XLVIII.

Mark or Sign is of three kinds : 1 positive and negative, 2 purely positive, and 3 purely negative. That which pervades both positively and negatively is positive-negative, as for instance, smokiness when fire is to be proved. “Where there is smoke, there is fire as in a kitchen” is positive concomitance.” Where there is no fire there is no smoke as in a lake” is negative con- comitance. Purely positive is that where there is positive concomitance only, e. g. pot is nameable because it is know- able like cloth. Here there is no negative concomitance of nameability or knowability as all things are knowable and nameable. Purely negative is that which has a negative concomit- ance only, e. g. earth differs from other things because it has smell; that which does not so differ has no smell, as water ; this is not like it; and hence it is not so. Here there is no positive instance (of a thing) that has smell ( and yet ) differs from others, because the whole earth forms the subject. 1. Having described the typical syllogism, the author now procdees to treat of the mark or middle term, which determines the character of the syllogism and also makes the inference valid or invalid. A mark may be true or false, and accordingly & ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å is either ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•Å or ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•Å, the latter be - ing usually termed arr. Before adverting to this dis-

‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏. tinction, it is necessary to tell what a mark in general means and how it usually stands in a syllogism. The author therefore first describes the three kinds of “The mark

The reason ‘mark.’

or

‚Ä¢

?

is of three sorts, positive and negative, merely positive, and merely negative. Of these the first is in invariable con- comitance with the Tr both affirmatively and negatively, as smokiness is with fire. The second has the invariable concomitance affirmatively only; and the third negatively only. An instance of the

it is knowable,’ because and

is A jar is nameable, for

‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®

the

renameability’ and the ‘knowability’ being here co-extensive, a negative concomitance of theirs, that is, a concomitance of their absolute negations is impossible. The properties of name- ability and knowability reside in all things, and so there is no ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ on which the ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ of ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø exists, and hence there

[[285]]

is no aften. The example of the third kind is Earth is distinct from all other padarthas, because it has odour. In this case there is a fargera where there is neither odour nor are as in water or air, but there is no ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ where both ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß and ‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ are con- comitant. In the second case therefore we can have only an ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, such as ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ò‡§ü‡•á, but no ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, such as ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø afa, owing to the impossibility of finding a corresponding ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§. In the third case we have a ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, because we have no less than 14 odourless things (the 8 dravyas besides earth, plus the remaining 6 padarthas), on which the gar

‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ (difference of earth from all other things) does not exist; but obviously we cannot have any area in this case, as neither ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß nor ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶, which is the same as ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ, exists anywhere but on graft. In the first case however we have both kinds of e, because we can have both similar and contrary instances. We can say ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•á, as well as ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§¶‡•á ‡•§ The chief test therefore of discovering to which of these three kinds a mark belongs is to see whether there is any ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§, that is, an instance in which the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø coexists with the g, and also a farger or a contrary instance in which ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ co-exists with ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ. If both kinds of in- stances are available then they as well as the inference in which it is employed are safe; secondly, if the first kind of instance alone is found and not the second, they are ; and lastly if the second only is found but not the first, they are ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø.

The essence of a qr therefore consists in the r being co-existent with all existent things. But an objector might say that the illustration iu the text is incorrect, since there are many things in the universe which have no names, and which we do not and cannot know, and yet of which the ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ or ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø-

can be predicated. But, says T. D., the way and r referred to are not those determined by our own limited capacity; they are absolute, and so though a thing may be unknown and unnamed to us, it is still the object of the omniscience of God.

  1. The case of tragautame is rather complicated. Its essence consists in the re being coter- Kevala-vyatireki. minous with qg, as in the example, grat ‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç.

How earth is prov- ed distinct from other substances.

T

  1. Here T. D. indulges in a little argument which is typical of the scholastic subtilities for which Naiyayikas have become so famous. An objector starts up saying that gar√Æq cannot be proved by inference on ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä, and he puts down a dilemma. The ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø . . ‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ is either previously known or not; if it is known to exist somewhere (elsewhere than earth of course), then the ( u ) either co-exists with it or not. Now if the co-exists with the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø in the other thing, then that is clearly & ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ and there is an en; but if the co-exists with it in no other thing than earth, then it is a peculiar characteristic of the qer, and there can be no sar and no inference based on it. On the other hand, if the itself is unknown, then of course there can be no agrafa; and for this reason. An ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø, such as ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç, is a ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®, that is, knowledge of a mountain, not pure and simple, but as af- E’ characterized by fire.’ But there is a maxim that a farare thing cannot be known without the previous know- ledge of the faiq; for how can we know a quga unless we first know what a quis. The knowledge of ada can- not therefore be had without our first having the knowledge of the ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø. But by our hypothesis the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡•® . ‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶, is unknown ; and hence there can be no ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø like ‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä. Similarly as the knowledge of an ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ depends on the knowledge of its ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø, the ‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ is also un- known, and hence there can be uo ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç A ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø syllogism is therefore an impos-

sibility.

  1. The above dilemma is fairly nettling, although our author does attempt to give some sort of a reply to it in the concluding portion of the commentary. The passage is involved in considerable obscurity. As read by all copies except one

A passage in Tarka-Dipik√¢ ex- plained.

SEOT. XLVIII. ]

Notes.

[[289]]

or rather two, it is quite unintelligible, and is probably corrupt; and I have therefore ventured to correct it, on the high authority of Nilakantha and the Ms. J, by transferring the words far to the preceding sentence, and splitting ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ into ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ. Read thus, the gist of the reply is briefly this. The re in the inference in question is not the cumulative difference of fourteen padarthas (8 substances +6 categories) from earth, which being unobserved on anything other than earth may be unfit to be & ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø. What is really intended to be proved on earth is the simultaneous existence of the thirteen mutual negations of those fourteen pad√¢rthas. Mutual nega- tion exists between two things, and so there are thirteen mutual negations, corresponding to the thirteen couples that can be formed out of fourteen padarthas, water etc., and residing in thirteen things, excluding that of which the negation is spoken of. Thus resides in the thirteen

e things, light etc.; and are resides in all things excepting light. Thus the thirteen mutual negations reside in thirteen things at a time, but on none of the fourteen things do all of them exist at one and the same time. They do however so exist on earth, and in this respect earth is distinguished from the fourteen things. Our area therefore here is ur- ‡§¶‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç, the simultaneous exis- tence of the thirteen mutual negations on one thing.’ And as no instance is known on which the existence of this r is previously ascertained, we cannot know whether the exists there or not; and having thus no knowledge of the

positive or negative, we can neither call it saft, nor arare. Thus the first horn of the objector’s dilemma is disposed of. The second, that the re being unknown there can be no e, is also weak, because we have seen that the area which we have taken, namely en- *, ’ aggregate of the thirteen mutual negations of water etc.’ is already known by the previous ascertainment of its thirteen components, the thirteen mutual negations

[[37]]

[[990]]

Tarka-Sangraha.

[ SHOT. XLVIII.

severally. But, the objector rejoins, though your thirteen negations may be severally known, their aggregate is still unascertained ; how can then the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø be called ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ? Well, replies the undaunted Naiy√¢yika, I do not recognize an aggregate() as a separate thing from its com- ponents, and my are here is not a fictitious thing like

, but the several negations themselves, which, being ascertained on their respective substratin (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ), may be inferred conjointly on earth. Consequently there ought to be uo difficulty in obtaining a ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø 8 well as a ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. The ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø inference is there- fore quite possible and valid.

Propriety of ke- vala-vyatireki.

  1. We have followed the tedious argument in T. D. simply to show into what absurdities the Naiyayikas have fallen by recognizing a hamari‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®. The essence of it, as ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø is pointed out above, is that there is co-terminous with a. The we cannot therefore be anything but a peculiar characteristic of ar. Now how can the peculiarity of a thing be known except by actual observation? The syllogism is quite incapable of discovering it. The conclusion in an inference is a particular deduction from the general proposi- tion, and being already contained in it, is not a new piece of knowledge. But an af is ex hypothese a new error fact, and capable of being known only by observation or by induction. This is the gist of the dilemma stated above. while the answer given by T. D. is most unsatisfactory.

**

Why then did the Naiydyikus at all recognize surattas

7 which involved them into so much absurdity. Two reasons might be suggested for this; oue is historical while the other is purely dialectical. The three-fold division of ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó and ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® is comparatively modern, but it is derived from Gotama’s division of ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å into ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ and ‡§µ‡•à‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£. * The

  • G. S. I, I, 34-5.SECT. XLVIII. ]

Notes.

[[291]]

two kinds of ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å made the ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£, ‡§â‡§™‡§®‡§Ø and ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡§® also two- fold; and thus the whole syllogism changed its character according as the was through similarity or dissimilarity.

became and the

The ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø or ‡§µ‡•à‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø referred to was that of ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§, and thus the gera was as it were the key to the whole syllogism. When the ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ was enlarged by the addition of the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø, and thereby sank itself into insignificance, the the means of determining the character of the ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® as regards their ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§µ‡•à‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø, or to use their modern equivalents ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ and ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ. So long as the distinction was confined to surf, there was nothing absurd or unintelligible about the doctrine; but the modern school of Naiyayikas in their zeal to carry each and every doctrine of the ancients to its ultimate result, discovered three ways in which the two kinds of a might be used in a syllogism, namely, either each alone by itself, or both optionally. In this way the mark (fay) became three-fold, according as it was followed by a ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø that was purely ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø, or purely ana, or both alternatively. Hence modern writers like Annambhatta define a ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó as one having an ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø 01 ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø- fata or both. As most inferences have both kinds of ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø the class of ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó is the largest and also the most general one, while the other two are exceptional cases which are classed apart bacause they cannot be included in the general category.

Objectons.

  1. In one sense both the ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á aud ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø may be said to be defective syllogisms, as lacking one or more characteristics that are re- quisite for a sound deduction. Properly speaking a deduction ought to be the inference of a particular or a less general proposition from a wider one; but in a - grafy the arfafarzigfafa is not only no particular case included in the af, but there is actually co-terminons with the widest generality, namely, Existence (T). Similarly in a ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø, the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø being co-terminous with

the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑

there is no middle term between the two, or if there happens to be one it is co-extensive with q and are (as

[[292]]

Turka–Sangraha.

[SECT. XLVIII.

in the example given in the text. The three terms being co-extensive, all the premises become equally wide and practically tautologous. The Naiyayikas themselves seem to have been half conscious of the precarious case of the - af, for the reply they give to a strong objection, some- times advanced against it, is anything but convincing. The objection is directed against ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø itself. ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø is the result of ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂, and ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂ is ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®, that is, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® which can arise only when the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ is known to reside in ‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡•Ç. Now in a ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ- ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ is the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø of ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É and hence the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ or ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø resides in ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ. But how can 1 ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø residing in one thing, namely wear, be the fa≈üƒ±q of a quite different thing, namely ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§® or ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó, and thus produce the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü- qgwfarana ? The Naiy√¢yikas, try to meet this difficulty by making ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ & property not of ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ but of ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ- ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®. .* The force of the objection is not however thereby much lessened. The difficulty in short is how can we infer fire from smoke from the invariable concomitance of their negations? Or to make it still more clear, if a

tenger be put in the English Celarent ( E A E ), of which the major premise, i. e. fata, is negative, the conclusion also must be negative, while in the Sanskrit Nyaya, we derive a positive conclusion ( qdar afgura) from a negative major premise. This is absurd. The reply of the Naiy√¢yikas is that though the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø may reside in ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ, the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§® is still known as the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø of its ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ which is ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï; and that sort of knowledge of the re being an accessory suffices to produce the requisite ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂. Hence S. C. says ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•Ä- ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø. But this is a lame explanation after all.

The use of kevala- vyatireki.

  1. The true reason for recognizing a safari agara seems to have been to avoid the necessity of having a fifth proof called afqra (Presumption). ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•á inference are instructive and deserve to be quoted in full:- ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ( ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ) ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ- ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡••

SECTIONS. IL, L, LI. ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É, ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö.

A subject is one where the thing to be proved is doubted, as mountain when smokiness is the reason.

A similar instance is one where the thing to be proved is ascertained, as kitchen in the same case.

Paksha, Sapak- sha and Vipaksha.

A contrary instance is that where the absence of the thing to be proved is ascertained, as a lake in the same case.

  1. In these three short sections, Annambha·π≠·π≠a defines three terms which constantly occur in connec- tion with the syllogism. “Aq, place or subject, is, that on which the existence of the thing to be ascertained is doubtful, as the mountain in an inference of fire from smoke. A gr or similar ins- tance is that on which the existence of the thing to be ascertained is already known, as the culinary hearth in the same inference. A far or contrary instance is that on which the negation of the thing to be ascertained is definitely known, as a great lake in the same inference.” Annambha·π≠·π≠a has given the simplest definitions of the terms, probably copied by him from Gungesa’s Tattva-Chintamani, while most of the others such as that of N. B. are merely variations of it. The rer and fer of later Naiyayikas of course correspond respectively to the instances by simi-
  • Ved. Par. Calc, ed. p. 14.

[[294]]

Tarka-Sangraha.

SEOT. LI.

larity and dissimilarity mentioned by Gotama, and are employed to illustrate ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø and ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø respectively.

An objection.

  1. The definition of q is however open to an objection. It is prima facie incorrect because it does not apply to cases where we infer a thing, even though it may have been previously ascertained by other proofs such as Perception or Word. We have for instance the injunction of the ≈öruti, eta arst E54: ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É * in which ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ is first direc- ted to be heard and then reflected, and then contemplated upon. aur is acquiring the knowledge of the Soul from the Vedas, while comprehends reasoning or inference. But how can inference work if the Soul is already ascertained by saur, and is therefore no longer? And yet the injunction being that of infallible ≈öruti cannot be groundless. It is not necessary therefore that the q in an inference must be af. Besides even in ordinary life we often practise inference, although the wre is actually observed or otherwise ascertained, as when we wish to corroborate our observation of fire on the mountain by the additional evidence of an inference. The definition of g is therefore inaccurate. The anthor’s reply to this objection is not quite clear. The true definition of ver, says T. D., is “a thing which is the sub- stratum of the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ as already defined, 2. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡§π- Gafferua:‚Äù.‚Ä† That is quite, true, but does the author there- by admit that the definition of ver given here is wrong? And if so, why did he insert it at all? The difficulty will, however, be removed by taking the word in the sense of, not doubtful absolutely, but doubtful for the time being, or doubt- ful in the precise way in which an inference ascertains the are. The star for instance might have been known from ≈öruti, but mere verbal knowledge of a thing is not sufficient to dispel all doubts and questionings which often obstruct the free working of the intellects. Arguments of both wre and
  • Brihad. √ér. Up. IV. 5, 6.

‚Ä† Vide Note 6 Under Sect. 44, p. 240, supra.

SECT. LI. ]

Notes.

[[205]]

aree kinds are needed to remove these doubts and make our knowledge absolutely certain. Similarly though fire may have been actually observed, our senses often mislead us, and there is no positive certainty until independent reasoning corroborates the evidence of our senses. In this sense of course there is still doubtful, even though it has been previously known.

What is a good hetu.

  1. It is rather strange that Amnambha·π≠·π≠a, after having described the general nature of a mark, did not, before proceeding to the re or invalid reasons, mention the distinctive characteristics of valid marks. The desideratum however has been supplied by the writers of other manuals, such as Tarka-Kaumudi and Tarkamrita. These essentials of are five, and are thus described in T. K.:-ami √¶√ä ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã‡§™‡§® ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É, ‡§Ö‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø-
  • The five requisites of a good are,-(1) existence on the qr, of course at the time of making the inference; (2) existence on gra zzrea; (3) non-existence on the g; (4) non-contradiction of the subject matter by another stronger proof; and (5) absence of a counter-balancing reason on the other side, proving the negation of area. The first three conditions are obviously deducible from what has been already said about the nature of the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑, ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑. The latter two belong to the matter rather than to the form of the inference. These fire requisites are necessarily present in an ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É Int the other twe, ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø and ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤- u, being exceptional, are by their very nature wanting in one requisite each, and therefore pass ou with four only. The ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø cannot have ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø because thore is no ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ in its cases while & ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø cannot have ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ owing to the absence of war itself. With these two excep- tions, the requisites are essential to all inferences, and the absence of any one of them gives rise to the several fallacies. Thus the want of ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æra produces ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß;

*T. K. Bom. ed. p. 12.

[[206]]

Tarka-Sangraha.

[ SECT. LI.

that of ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ and ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§É that of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß and ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞; and the absence of the last two gives rise to ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ aud ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ respectively. This will be fully understood when the nature of the several fallacies has been explained.

Another view.

  1. The author of Nyaya-Bindu mentions only the first three as the requisites of a good, omitting the last two, perhaps because they pertain more to the matter than to the form of the, and involve what are called material fallacies. He describes this ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å thus :– " ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®- ‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•á (‡•¶. ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ) ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ- √† fata ‚Ä† The Vaiseshikas too would seem to recognize * ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å. The whole Nydya theory of valid reasons and the five kinds of fallacies is as a matter of fact deduced from this three-fold character of the .

SECT. LII.

ATET:.

There are five fallacies, viz: -1. Discrepancy, diction, 3 Ambiguity, 4 Futility and 5 Falsity.

Fallacies.

2 Contra-

  1. The next six sections deal with the five groups of fallacies, an accurate knowledge of which is necessary to ensure sound reasoning. It is often as necessary to know what we are to avoid as to know what we are to accept, and hence a treatise on Logic can never be complete without a descrip- tion of the various fallacies to which an inference is liable. The word game is capable of two derivations and two meanings. It means a fallacious reason, (getag:) if dis- solved either as that which looks like a but

‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á is not ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å, ’ or as ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§É ’that which resembles a ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å. ’ If dissolved as bat: bat arss√¶rer: the word would mean a fallacy (Tiq: ). i. e. the error which underlies the ap- parent and makes it invalid. The difference between the two meanings is important, because it must be noted that the five-fold divison of fallacies is really based on the different kinds of ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑ and not on those of ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å..

  • V. S. Up. Calc. ed. p. 160.

‚Ä† Nyaya-Bindu-Tika Bib. In. p. 104,

SBOT. LII. ]

Notes.

[[297]]

The reason of this distinction is that a single may often be vitiated by two or more errors occurring at once, each of which would fall under oue or the other of the five classes; but their combination will not make a separate: kind of ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏. Such a ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å might in fact be classed under as many heads as there are fallacies involved in it. Thus if we take the syllogism, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§π will be found to fall under all the five heads ofrere. Simi- larly in ‡§ò‡§ü‡§É ‡§™‡§¢‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç, the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ has fallacies of all kinds, In -‡§π‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç, the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å is of three kinds: ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§, ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß; while in ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§É, the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å would be both ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ and ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß. If the division had been applied to geig instead of gety, how could these mixtures of several fallacies have been classed ? They can neither be put under one only of the possible heads, nor form an independent class. Hence Naiyayikas have adopted the better plan of classifying all the fallacies or errors that are possible in a g, and then denominating a ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å

which possessed one or more of them as fallacious in so many ways. The author of Didhiti remarks to the same effect : ’ ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‘‡§Ö‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§É, ’ ’ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ’ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ- ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç -’ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æs‡•ã‡§™‡§ó‡§§ ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•å ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§É that is, ‚ö´ the fallacious reasons are divided into five classes not be- cause only five varieties of them are possible, but because the errors which underlie them are of so many kinds. The correct method for a Nyaya writer would therefore be to classify and define the five rs or fallacies and then to define a geag as one that is infected with one or more of them.

[[3]]

  1. Annambha·π≠·π≠a has avoided the difficulty by simply enumerating in the text only the five kinds of gigs without defining ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏ (‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å ) in general, and then adding the definition of a 4 as added in T. D. The remark of Nilakantha shows that the word arrer is used by the author in two different senses in the text and in the com- mentary. In the text it means a grad, since the five class- names given are names of thes, while the definition in T. D. is that usually given of a. The five errors in a corresponding to the five as mentioned in the text

[[38]]

[[208]]

Tarha-Sangraha.

[SECT. LII.

are given by N. B., as anar (discrepancy), fatru (con- trariety), arg (counter-balance) efa (inconclusive- ness) and are (absurdity). The five apparent reasons which derive their names from these errors are respectively called

fare ( discrepant, or inconsistent), fase ( contrary ), ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ( counter-balanced ), ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ( inconclusive ) and ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ (absurd or futile ).

of reason.

J

  1. T. D. defines a ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑ as ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É, ’that which is the subject of a right know- Errors or defects ledge which prevents a judgment. The errors named above prevent a conclusion that would otherwise follow from the reason given. Thus in the syllogism ‡§π‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤, the judgment that the lake is fiery would follow in due course, if it were not for our certain knowledge that there is no smoke on the lake. This knowledge becomes theretore ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï, and the subject of that knowledge, namely the absence of smoke ou the lake, becomes a ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑. But why say ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® : The word warf is used to prevent an erroneous knowledge of a ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑ from obstructing even a valid ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø. As for example, our familiar syllogism ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç may be opposed by an erroneous perception that there is uo fire on the mountain. The game however being only a ¬•¬§ ought not to make the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å in ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§ ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ etc.; and hence the restriction that the knowledge of ar or any other must itself be right, knowledge, and not a w merely.

  2. The definition however is imperfect in another way, because it does not cover those ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑s, such as ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, which do not prevent ar ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø directly but only indirectly, by preventing ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® or ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® or ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂, and are thus ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß themselves so far as gr√¢tƒÅvarer is concerned. Nilakantha therefore remarks, ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ú‡§π‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§§‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡•á‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É. The word ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø in the definition is to be cnlarged so as to include ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ that is ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® or

SEOT. LII. ]

Notes.

[[299]]

‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®, whatever it may be. In this way ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ and other ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑s which directly affect the ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ only but not the sara, will be included in the definition. The same result might be obtained, says the author of the Didhiti, by taking ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø to mean not a simple judgment ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶, but faforeig√Æata, as angeurergmara v√•d af. Other writers like T. K. avoid the difficulty by actually introducing the word ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ after ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø in the definition.

Erroneous reasons or fallacies.

  1. After knowing what a r is, it is easy to define a ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å as ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç. Another definition of a ty given by T. B. and ≈öankara Misra is ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ó‡§Æ- ‡§ï‡•å‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§É ’ wanting in any of the five or four requisites of a good. This latter definition is simpler as well as more scientific, because it takes away the necessity of recognizing so many geres, all of which can in fact be reduced to the absence of one Or more of the five requisites of a ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•Å.

  2. Although all writers are practically agreed as to the definition of a rare, there is no such unanimity about their number. The chief divergence of views is between the Nai- y√¢yikas, who on the authority of Gotama recognize five fallacious reasons mentioned by Annambhatta, and the Vais- eshikas, who following Kanada accept only three, namely, ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß. The divergence is not however radical, for the last two, a¬∂g and anfura, which Gotama enumerates separately, are included by Vaiseshikas either under ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß or under ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ or ‡§Ö‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï as it is often called. Again the names of the several genres are not the same in all books. Gotama names the five as weura- ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§Æ, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ aud ‡§Ö‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤. + of these the first two are identical with those given by Annambha·π≠·π≠a. or is defined as that which leaves the conclusion

  • V. S. Up. Calc. ed. p. 159.

‚Ä† Ibid p. 150

‚Ä°Q S. I, 2, 45.

[[300]]

Tarka–Sangraha.

SEOT. LII.

doubtful, owing to the opposition of an equally strong argu- ment on the other side,* and is therefore the same on our ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑. A ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å is that which is as doubtful as the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, and which is therefore ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§ corresponds to our af. Kanada’s aphorism‚Ä† is a little obscure, but his doctrine is unmistakably summed up in the verse of an un- known writer, quoted by Prasastap√¢da, federa¬§√≠og artrutsaat‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ’ Kasyapa or Kanada declared three false reasons, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß and ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß ’ Of these ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß are the same as ours, while ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß corresponds to ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ or ‡§Ö‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‚Ä¢ A fourth one named ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ is also added by some writers, but it is, says Sankara Misra, identical with ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø and therefore comes under ‡§Ö‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï. Bad- dhists, like the author of Ny√¢ya-Bindu, adopt the enum- eration and terminology of Kanada. The sub-divisions of ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ßappear to be the work of modern writers.

Formal and Mate- rial fallacies.

  1. It is obvious that the difference between Gotama and Kanada mainly lies in the recognition of ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ and ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§. These together form a separate group of material fallacies, as distinguished from the other three,which may for convenience be called formal fallacies. Many European logicians regard material fallacies as being out of the province of logic, and a similar reason may have prompted Kanada to exclude re- ‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ and ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ from his list of ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏s. The exclusion of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ and ‡§Ö‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ, ( which correspond to the two treteras ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ and ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§) by some writers from among the five requisites of a good may be accounted for on the same ground. It must. however be stated to prevent any misunder- standing, that there is in Indian Logic no such clearly-marked division of formal and material fallacies as was laid down by Aristotle under the two names of fallacia in dictione, and fallacia extra dictionem. It will be found later on that some varieties of ‡§Ö‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß when reduced to an English syllogism, disclose material fallacies, while others are formal
  • G. S. 2, 48. ‚Ä† V. S. III. I, 15.SECT. LIII. ]

Notes.

[[301]]

fallacies. The fact is that the peculiar form of Sanskrit syllogism did not permit a clear demarkation of formal form material fallacies, nor are the two so separated in practice. Most of the so-called formal fallacies involve material miscon- ceptions or over-statements, while almost all the material fallacies can be avoided by a strict adherence to the syllogistic form. The distinction is purely artificial, and has not been

observed by the Naiy√¢yikas.

SECT. LIII,

affair:

The discrepant reason is one that coexists partially. It is threefold, over-wide, peculiar and non-exclusive. One that coexists with negation of the thing to be proend is over-wide; e, g, mountain is fiery because it is knowable, since knowability exists with absence of fire on a lake. Peculiar is that which is not found either in similar or contrary instances; e. y. Sound is eternal because it is Word. The genus word is absent from all eternal and non-eternal things, and resides in Sound only. Non-exclusive is that which has neither similar nor dis- similar instances; e. g. Every thing is transitory because it is knowable. Here everything being the subject of inference there is no separate example.

Discrepant rea-

SOB.

‡§π‡•Ç‡§Å

  1. ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ is ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ’that which involves a zafrane or discrepancy of the g with the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø.’ It is defined as ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï, or co- existing with the art only partially.’ Thus if one says ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É (‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂- ari ) ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á , the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å will be ‡§Ö‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï or aufrufta, because there are the earthy atoms which though ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§µ‡§§‡•ç are ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø just as there is ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø which is both ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂ and ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø. Hence the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø is not correct; that is, the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å co- exists partially with the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, partially with the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ, and entirely with neither. Vatsyayana explains the word ‡§Ö‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï as, ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•á‡§ø ‡§ê‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç * ‡•§ The word ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ implies the same thing, for ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ or ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ has been defined ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç, that is, it is a property which leads to the proof of both ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø and its negation, and thus causes donbt about the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø’- The ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ has a tendency to prove both ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø and its negation because it is coexistent with both; and the
  • Fat. on. G. ¬ß, 1, 2, 56.

!

Tarka-Sangraha..

[ SEOT. LIII.

simultaneous knowledge of these two extremes, produces ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π of the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø which is ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®. Hence Kanidr calls ‡§Ö‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï by the name of ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß.

Its three varieties.

Over-wide mark.

‚Ä¢

  1. raefeart is sub-divided into three varieties ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ (Over-wide), ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£, (Peculiar) and ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™ - ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä (Non-exclusive ). Of these ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ or the over-wide mark is that which is found both on the rg and the farer, that is, which co-exists both with are and its negation. Annambha·π≠·π≠a defines a rar simply as one that coexists with rear, but the full definition would be that given by T. K. ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. The reason why Annambhatta omits ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ from his definition is that it is necessarily implied in an ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å such as the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ is, and need not therefore be particularly mentioned. As an illustration of error the author gives “Mountain is fiery, because it is knowable”; where the reason knowability,’ exists both in things known to possess fire as the ordinary hearth, and also things that have no fire, as a lake. The ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ being thus associated with both ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø and ‡§¨‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ, there is no reason why one should be inferred from it and not the other; but both cannot exist together and hence the g is fallacions. Similarly in ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§É, the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø is ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£, being found to co-exist both with a in agra

‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ in ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§≤‡§ï.

{

and with

  1. The ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ or Peculiar is just the opposite of ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£, being found neither in ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ nor in ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑. Its absence in the farer is of course natural. because even a good is non-existent in

Peculiar mark.

‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑; but the fallacy of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ consists in its being absent in er also. If the Tor is over-wide, owing to its trespassing in the forbidden reason of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑, this is not wide enough as it does not even cover the legitimate ground of . One errs on the side of excess, the other on that of defect; and thus both are equally falla- cious. The ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£, in fact, as its

its name denotes

SEOT. LIII. ]

Notes.

[[303]]

is a peculiar characteristic of the qr which exists nowhere else, and for which therefore no agere can be found. As for example, if we say, “Sound is eternal, because it has the nature of sound,” the nature of sound, a, is a peculiar characteristic of sound; and being so, can lead to no valid conclusion. In this case the Ter instances, e. g. those having the area fer, would be ether and other eternal things, while the far instances would be all non-eternal products, such as a jar. They exists in neither, and

hence it is called ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£-

Non-exclusive

mark.

<

  1. The third variety of ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ is ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ (Non-exclu- sive) which is defined in the text as one that has neither & ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ nor a ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§, ’ that is, which is never present where the TET is present, excepting of course the r itself. Now this can happen only when all things in this world are in- cluded in qr, and so nothing is left outside the range of ver that can be denominated ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑. The definitions given in T. K. and T. A. make this quite clear. They are, ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§É or ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§É, ‘one in which the universality of things is the qer,’ that is one in which the wrer is unascer- tained ( vara ) of all things in the world, and there is there- fore no ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ where the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø or its negation might be said to be ascertained (fra). The example given in the text is “All things are transient, because they are know- able " where ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ being the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑, there is no ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ apart from it. But why cannot the individuals, says an objector, serve as we or far that is, why cannot we argue, ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ò‡§ü‡•á ‡§™‡§ü‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§°‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ? It cannot be said that the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø being ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß in ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ, it is necessarily so in ‡§ò‡§ü, ‡§™‡§ü and ‡§ï‡•Å‡§°‡§ö ; for first the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ( ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ) may be ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ in the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ at one time, and be ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß at another; and secondly uncertainty as to the whole does not necessarily imply an equal uncertainty as to individuals or some parts of that whole. ‡§ò‡§ü and ‡§™‡§ü therefore which are certainly transient might very well serve as #THEZIFA to prove enfara ou af. To remove this objection modern

Tarka-Sangraha.

SMOT. LIII.

Naiyayikas define un ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø 05 ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§É ‘one in which the is only positively connected with the and so there is neither & ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø nor & ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§. But this latter definition also is faulty, as it would apply even to & ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•Å. The proper answer to the first objection would be that in an agr√©gnf√®, although there may be indi- vidual things in which the ear is ascertained, there is no ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø either of the ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø or of the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø kind, since the conclusion itself constitutes the widest possible genera- lization. The name gift, (Non-exclusive) is given to this fallacy because the a being universal nothing is excluded from it.

  1. Now it may be asked, why are these three fallacies, ap- parently so dissimilar, and the last a quite anomalous case, classed under

? A closer examination of the definitions and examples of the three varieties will how- ever show that there is a common principle underlying the division, and that principle is derived from the general definition of ear itself.

&

A wahrene or discrepant reason has been defined as one which is not uniformly concomitant with are, that is, which uniformly exists neither with ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø nor with ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ. It

The three-fold di- vision explained.

[[9]]

two requisites of a gag, Now there are four and

is neither purely ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø, nor purely ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø, nor both com - pletely, but half of this and half of that. It is thus defective in either or both of the namely, ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. only four ways in which the two properties may be pre- dicated of a , namely, both may be present, both may be absent, or either may be present when the other is absent. Thus we have four cases: (1) presence of both wygra and fargsurfer; (2) absence of both of them; (3) presence of ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ, but absence of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø; (4) absence of ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ but presence of fargranata. The first is undoubtedly a case of wag, as both the requisites are present, and may therefore he left out.. In the latter three cases the is

SMOT. LIII. 1

Notes.

[[305]]

obviously defective, and is respectively called agr√©gn?, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø has been defined as one that has neither a ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ nor a furere‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§; that is, there is no ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ on which the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å co-exists with ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, nor a ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ from which the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å is ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§ just as the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø is. ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø has therefore neither of the two properties, ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. The third case is that of a rerror which is defined as existing both on the ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ and the ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑; that is, there is ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ but no ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. The fourth is ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ which, as non- existing on both wer and far instances, possesses only ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, but not ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ. The three varieties are thus nothing but the three possible ways in which the fanffata (defectiveness) of a fer may occur.

Keval√¢nvayi and Kevalavyatireki distinguished.

  1. One more point remains to be noticed in connection with these, and especially the last two ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£, namely, in what re- spect they do respectively differ from - ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø and ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•Ås. The in- stances of ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ given in the text are very similar to those given for ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø and ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø, and no distinction can at first sight be made between the two pairs. A comparison of the illustrations will however show the difference. Thus ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç is a ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£, while ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç is a ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø. The difference bea tween the two lies in the r which is co-extensive with the in the latter case, but not so in the first. Similarly ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç or ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡•§ is ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§ø while ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç will be ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£, the difference being the same, namely, that there in a baccurate is co-extensive with the, but not so in the rear. Now why should this difference make one a good and the other a bad inference? The reason is obvious. When the T and

coincide with each other, there is no are or discre pancy between the two, although we cannot always have a ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ or free‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§. The essence of ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ lies not so much in the absence of ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§π‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§, but in the imperfect generalization, the absence of the area only indi- cating the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ or defect in the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.

[[39]]

[[306]]

Tarka-Sangraha.

SECT. LIV. Aaza:

[ SHOT. LIV

Contrary reason is that which is percnded by the negation of the thing to be proved, e. y. Sound is eternal because it is created. Creatibility is covered by the negation of eternity or‚Äú, - transitoriness.

  1. for contrary reason is that which is less ex- tensive than the negation of me and is never coexistent with greq.’ As when we

Contrary reason.

Êâá

say, Sound is eternal, because it is artifi- cial,’ the reason, artificialness’ coincides with fear or ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ and not with ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ. We have the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ arera ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ò‡§£‡•ç‡§ü‡•á, but not ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç. The ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å area being thus ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø, it becomes a ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï or ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å of that ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ, and not of its ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µs that is, the artificialness of sound is exactly the reason why sound should be non-eternal. Thus the fallacy consists in drawing a conclusion just contrary to that which would be justified by the reason. This accords well with Gotama’s definition fagra- ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ’ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß is that which is contrary to the conclusion desired to be drawn.’

  1. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß differs from ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ in never existing on the —á as the latter does; while it differs from errareor in existing on the unlike the latter which does not. The chief distinction between far and face is that in the former the r is only imperfect or defective, while in the latter it is actually contrary. There is only a discre- pancy in the first; there is direct opposition in the second.

SECT. LV.

enf√†gg:

The ambiguous or inconclusive reason is that wherein there is another reason proving the negation of the thing to be proved; e. g. Sound is eternal, because it is audible like any other sound; and sound is non-eternal, because it is a creation like a jar.

*G. S. I, 2, 47.

SBOT. LY.

Notes.

[[307]]

The rear differs from a fa in this, that while in the latter the very same which ought to prove arra is given as a reason for proving the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, in ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å which proves ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ is different ( ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ) from

Satpratipaksha or Counter-balanced

reason.

that actually given. For example, if we say ‘Sound is eternal, because it is apprehended by the organ of hearing’, the given, namely ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ, does not prove ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ; but neither does it prove ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ. The ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ however is proved by another, a, in such an inference as, Sound is non- eternal, because it is artificial. In the is incon-

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å sistent with are in the same inference; in erfarer it is incon- sistent with the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø in a contrary inference. ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ is classed by Vaiseshikas under faa, of which it is in one sense a species; but there is a clear distinction between the two. In afaa the wrer of the inference in question is actual- ly disproved by a stronger proof of another kind, such as perception; as for instance, if one says “Fire is cold be- cause it is a substance,” the area is proved to be false by our actual perception of the heat of fire, according to the maxim ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á. In ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ there is no such ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß of the inference by a stronger proof, but only a counter- balancing of two inferences, which being of equal weight, are mutually destructive, but neither prevails over the other. This peculiarity of fare was well expressed by the more significant name,

(Inconclusive) which Gotama gave it, Gotama’s definition of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§Æ is ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ * ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ is an argument, and its ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ is the curiosity (‡§ú‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ) or expectancy (‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ) which is creat- ed in the course of the argument, and remains until it is satisfi- ed by a certain and well-grounded conclusion. An inference which is inconsequential owing to being counter-balanced [or opposed by a contrary inference of equal weight] does not remove this ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ; and hence & ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§Æ is defined as a which though propounded for the purpose of giving a certain conclusion (farang:) leaves the expecta- tion of a certain conclusion unfulfilled.’ It is therefore sur¬¨ ‡§∏‡§Æ) that is, as Vatsyayant explains it, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É always remaining in the stage of a non-concluded argu.. ment. The word water also conveys the same sense, but rather distantly. The author of dhiti interprets it as a

  • G. S. I, 2, 48.

C

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£-

[[308]]

Tarha-Sangraha.

[ SHOT. LV.

( ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡•§ To understand this derivation, it must be observed that when there are two mutually destructive inferences containing the two as that are warfarer of each other, the judgment is impeded because the two gs give rise to distinct as leading to quite contrary conclusions. It is needless perhaps to point out that a weaver is such, only so long as it is of equal weight with its contrary ( ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã- ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§É). As soon as the ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ becomes stronger by any reason, the former ceases to be a farer, and becomes a a Thus if there are two arguments, one in harmony with the ≈öruti or any other rar, and the other opposed to it, the other one is an on account of the greater weight of the former.

SECT. LVI.

f√®re:

Futile reason is of three sorts: having non-existent subject, nonexistent reason, and non-existent concomitance. Non-existent subject is thus:-Skyey lotus is fragrant because it is a lotus like a lotus in a lake. Here skyey lotus is the subject, but it does not exist at all. A Non-existent reason is this Sound is a quality because it is ocular. Here Sound is not ocular as it is audible. Non-existent concomitance is one which in- volves a limitation or condition. Condition is that which pervades the thing to be proved, but is not pervaded by the reason. Pervasion of the thing to be proced means not having absolute negation co-existent with the thing; while non-per- vasion by reason means having absolute negation co-existing with the reason. In ’the mountain is smoky because it has fire,’ contact with wet fuel is the condition. For instance, wherever there is smoke there is contact of wet fuel. Wherever there is fire, there is no contact of wet fuel; e. g. there is no contact of wet fuel in an iron ball. Thus wet fuel is the condition because it pervades the thing to be proved and is not pervaded by the reason. Fieriness is a futile reason owing to the condition.

  1. The fourth ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏ is ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ’ inconclusive or unproved reason, which Gotama calls wa(similar to ), on account of its being as doubt- ful as the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø. * An ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å is one that

eng

Asiddha or Incon- clusive reason.

[[7]]

has the ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑ called ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø is defined by Udaya-

  • G. S. I, 2, 49.

SHOT. LVI. ]

Notes.

[[309]]

fare (which gives rise knowledge of ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂. As

ndcharya as ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ’ absence of the ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø which consists in the true cognition of the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å as a property of the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É’ or, briefly speaking, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø is the non-production of ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂. Hence ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø has been defined as any cause, other than a to ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ), which obstructs the ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂ (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®) is composed of three elements, corresponding to the three terms of the syllogism, namely ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ and ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§r or ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§æ, the obstruction to the knowledge off will be caused by a defect or error in the apprehension of any of its three constituents. Thus an naturally resolves into three varieties, formed according as the error lies in the knowledge of, or of or of ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. The first is called ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, the second ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, and the third ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß.

First kind of Asiddha.

  1. Annambha·π≠·π≠a only enumerates the three varieties, without defining either are in general or its first two varieties. erg is defined as ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§É, that is ‘a ‡§π‡•á‡§§ the subject or place of which is devoid of the distinctive character of the supposed qr.’ Thus in the example, ‚ÄúA sky-lotus is fragrant, because it is a lotus,” the reasoning would be correct if the qr sky-lotus had been a real thing; but being only an imaginary thing, it is devoid of the essence of the supposed, namely, a. Here the qr is not ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ simply, but ‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü Or ‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶, and hence the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§ï or the essence of ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ is ‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ which never exists on an arr. In this case, being misled by the metaphorical application of the word ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ to ‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ we attribute the qualities of a real lotus to a fictitious thing,the existence of which is quite hypothetical or unproved. Here the rearr‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§ï‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ is ‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, because it distinguishes ‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§∞- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶, the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ in this ense, from other lotuses; and as ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ itself is a real thing, the falsity of mare must be due to the non-existence of its er, the andru, according to the maxim, when a property predicated of a qualified thing (fare) cannot reside in the qualified (fast), it is attri- buted to the qualification ( ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£- ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ). In the present instance there is on the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ the

[[310]]

Tarka-Sangraha.

[SHOT. LVI.

non-existence of the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§ï‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ, that is, ‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ. An ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø or ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ however may be ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß in two ways, either by being altogether non-existent, as in the above example, or by wanting the character of ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§æ, that is, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π etc. Take, for example, ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç. Here the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å being identical with the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ( ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ), the argument is mere fara, ‘proving what is already proved.’ As there is no fa here, the rar is wanting in the essential character of T, and is therefore en. Hence T. D. remarks under the next section that according to ancients ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§® comes under ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, while moderns regard it as a separate fur and not a fallacy.

  1. The second variety

The second kind,

and non-existence, is so called, because in it the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å itself is ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, .. non-existent on the q; as in the example given in the text, the gargar does not

‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ exist on ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶. Other examples of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß are ‡§µ‡•ç‡§π‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶, ‡§ò‡§ü‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§™‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç, or ‡§∂‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø- pat faar√≠orara, in all of which it will be marked that the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å is non-existent on the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑. It differs from ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß in this, that in the latter the errare is either false or not a proper ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑, while in the former, both ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å and ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø may be real things but there is no connection between them, or rather the negation of ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å, and not the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å, resides in the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß has many sub-varieties, such as ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß aud ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, all of which ultimately resolve into the general characteristic that the, as it is taken, is non-existent on the rer. In this respect

may be said to be complimentary to ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞, ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ and ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§. The three varieties of ere, as has been already shown, turn on the existence or the non-existence of two of the five requisites of a ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å, namely ‡§∏‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, while matary and are due to the neglect of the last two requisites, and is due to the absence of the first and the most important requisite, namely rare. Not that the is unreal or non-existent in itself, but that it lacks the

! 1SHOT. LVI.

Notes.

[[311]]

essential character of ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§æ, namely ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ. The real deti - nition of a ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß therefore is ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç.

The third kind.

a

  1. erant, non-existent concomitance or improper limitation, is defined by Annambhatta as ‘a mark which has a ( suppressed ) condition (a), that is, which is true conditionally only. T. K. and the older writers generally define it as ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§ï‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É ’ & mark which is devoid of the distinguishing attribute that is necessary to make it re- ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø. When the, in the form in which it is given, is not known to be invariably accompanied by the re, it is not ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø, that is, its ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ is ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß or doubtful. Such a ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å is wanting in the proper ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§ï‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ, either by excess when it is too generally stated, or by defect when it is unnecessarily restricted by a limitation that might be totally false or superfluous. Any way the is different from what it ought to be, and its rear is therefore questionable. A ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å does not exist on the ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É while a ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß is not invariably associated with ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø. In one the grafar is vitiated; in the other the ma is faulty. The stock example is ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§ ’the mountain is fiery because it has golden smoke.’ Here although mere ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ is ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ is not, for the additional epithet makes it a different thing which is not invariably associated with fire. In this example the su ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§ï ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ is not mere yaa but ‡§ï‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ or rather ‡§ï‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ, which does not exist on the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å : and hence ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ is ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß.

Difference bel- ween ancients and moderns.

  1. So far there is not much difference of opinion, but an- cients and moderns are as usual divided as to the exact scope of this fallacy. In the above example, the epithet renner is not only superfluous, but makes the unreal. Suppose how- ever we have ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç. Here although the adjective is superfluous, it does not make the actually false, and the argument will in spite of it be valid. Hence

[[312]]

Tarka-Sangraha.

[ SECT. LVI.

the moderns do not regard it as a case of errer, but only a fault of language, called aft (tautology). The ancients. however include the case under ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, becanse ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤er, being a needless limitation of, is as misleading as F√ÜFATT, and cannot therefore be the proper ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§ï ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ. The reason why this is regarded as sertranfire fallacy by the ancients appears to be that the addition of the qualifica- tion are conveys by implication that unqualified v is not ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø, and that it is the limitation ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ that brings it within the pale of the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø. ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ thus becomes zurcqarodge, which it really is not.

  1. Now this en

Non-concomitance is of two kinds.

of and may occur in two ways, either when the concomitance is not proved owing to its non-observance in any other place, or when it is actually proved to be false owing to the presence of some 3 or condition. Accordingly there are two varieties of ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, (1) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á- ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É ’ Dot concomitant with ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É’ and ( 2 ) ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï- ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ’ concomitant with ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø only conditionally. The instance of the first is ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ß‡§®‡§É, where the invariable concomitance of ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ and ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ is not proved. The cases of ‡§ï‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ and ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ would also apparently come under this class, because there too the an is not proved. The other variety is that of a conditional ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø and is ordinarily known as ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å. The familiar example of & ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï is ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§É, where ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø is not absolutely, but becomes so only when we add the condition andq√¨√† wi√¢; that is, fire in general is not invariably accompanied by smoke, but fire in contact with wet fuel is. Hence the in this case, namely af, is maders- ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø only when we add to it the limitation ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç. The is too widely stated and requires to be restricted to make the arra true. In one sense this case is the converse of

—è. In that case the fallacy consisted in the addition of an unnecessary restriction, while in this, it con- sists in the omission of a necessary one. In both cases, however,

SHOT. LVI. ]

Notes.

[[313]]

the squaredge is equally false, and hence the general defini- tion of a crane applies to both.

Annambha·π≠·π≠a’s definition.

.

  1. After having comprehended what are really is, the student will be in a position to understand and correctly estimate An- nambhatta’s statement that a me ty is ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß. There is a difference of opinion as to the true meaning of this statement. S. C. takes it as a definition of sangenare, but it will be seen from what has been said above that can properly be a definition of only one kind of an, and does not at all apply to instances like. On the other hand Nilakantha seems to take the statement not as a definition, but as a reply to those who class ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï as a separate ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏. The inter- pretation of Nilakantha would undoubtedly be preferable, as it saves the author from a palpable error; but there is against it the unequivocal statement of T. D. - ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï ‡§á‡§§‡§ø. We have no choice therefore bnt to agree with S. C. in taking the sentence as a definition. There are only two suppositions on which Annambha·π≠·π≠a’s definition can be reconciled with the general doctrine of ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß. Either he included instances like ‡§ï‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø- ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§É Hara ander ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï itself, or he relegated them to some other head of Tre. Both sup- positions are plausible and may be partly true. In the in- ference, for example, ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç we can conceive of an ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø such as ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø, or ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø, so that ether and other eternal things may not be grfor simply be- cause they exist. Thus the ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ will be ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï. Simi- larly we might regard ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶ as an instance of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ- fire, since, there being no such thing as awwwym in the world, the is non-existent on the war. In this manner we can perhaps justify Annambhatta’s definition; but the fact that it is inconsistent with the express views of other eminent authorities such as Ganges≈õa, Raghunatha, and Vi≈õ- van√°tha is undeniable. On the other hand there is a distinct school of writers who exclude even the
